Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were 54 men and women with temporomandibular dysfunction-related orofacial pain (TMD) enrolled in a study of brief (6 weeks) standard conservative treatment (STD) or standard treatment plus CBT (STD+CBT).

Participants.evidence: Patients were 54 men and women with temporomandibular dysfunction-related orofacial pain (TMD)

Intervention.evidence: brief (6 weeks) standard conservative treatment (STD) or standard treatment plus CBT (STD+CBT)

Objective.evidence: The purpose of this study was to determine whether cognitive-behavioral treatment (CBT) operates by effecting changes in cognitions, affects, and coping behaviors in the context of painful episodes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Momentary affects, pain, and coping processes were recorded on a cellphone keypad four times per day for seven days prior to treatment, and for 14 days after treatment had finished, in an experience sampling paradigm.

Result_Outcome.evidence: STD+CBT patients reported greater decreases in pain than did STD patients, significantly greater increases in the use of active cognitive and behavioral coping, and significantly decreased catastrophization.
